channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Explorer dies in Antarctic crossing
item.description: Explorer Henry Worsley dies during a solo attempt to cross Antarctica and complete the unfinished journey of his hero Sir Ernest Shackleton.

item.title: Lord Cecil Parkinson dies aged 84
item.description: Lord Parkinson, who as Conservative chairman played a key role in Margaret Thatcher's 1983 election victory, has died aged 84.

item.title: Zika virus 'to spread across Americas'
item.description: The Zika virus is likely to spread across nearly all of the Americas, the World Health Organization has warned.

item.title: Unlawful killing option for Hillsborough
item.description: The jury at the Hillsborough inquests is told one of its options is to consider whether the 96 victims of the disaster were unlawfully killed.

item.title: East Asia cold snap 'kills 85 in Taiwan'
item.description: A cold snap sweeping across East Asia kills at least 85 people in Taiwan and strands 60,000 tourists in South Korea.

item.title: US storm to bring heavy rain to UK
item.description: Heavy rain and gale-force winds are set to batter western parts of the UK with the arrival of the storm that hit the US with blizzards.

item.title: Fifth sperm whale found dead on coast
item.description: A whale is washed up on the Lincolnshire coast, following the discovery of three carcasses near Skegness and the death of a beached whale in Norfolk.

item.title: Hooker Hartley named England captain
item.description: Controversial hooker Dylan Hartley, with bans totalling 54 weeks, succeeds Chris Robshaw as England rugby union captain.

item.title: Millions battle US snow travel chaos
item.description: Millions of commuters across the eastern US have started the work week with frustrations after a major blizzard left transit systems frozen.

item.title: New-style IS targeting Europe - Europol
item.description: So-called Islamic State has developed a new style of combat to target Europe, Europol says, as the law enforcement agency opens a new counter-terror unit.

item.title: BBC may ask over-75s to pay TV licence
item.description: The BBC is considering asking people who are over 75 to give up their free TV licence if they can, or to make a voluntary contribution to its cost.

item.title: Tube strike called off by union
item.description: A 24-hour Tube strike planned for Tuesday evening has been called off after the Rail, Maritime and Transport (RMT) suspended industrial action.

item.title: VIDEO: David Cameron EU news conference
item.description: David Cameron is holding a news conference following his meeting with the Irish Prime Minister Enda Kenny.

item.title: VIDEO: Roofs collapse under weight of US snow
item.description: Aerial footage shows the extent of the damage caused by record snowfall on the East Coast of the US.

item.title: VIDEO: Aerial video shows 'frozen' East Asia
item.description: Aerial footage has shown the extent of a cold snap sweeping across East Asia - including frozen lakes and mudflats.

item.title: VIDEO: British rowers complete ocean odyssey
item.description: Four British women have become the first all-female team and the first team of four to row the Pacific.

item.title: VIDEO: Explorer dies 30 miles from Antarctic goal
item.description: A British adventurer has died while attempting to become the first person to cross the Antarctic unsupported.

item.title: VIDEO: Panda man's snow challenge to Tian Tian
item.description: Maryland-based Jeffrey Perez dressed up as a panda imitating the snow-based actions of the Smithsonian Zoo's Tian Tian.

item.title: VIDEO: Undercover report reveals IS recruitment
item.description: A BBC undercover report reveals the extent to which the so-called Islamic State use social media to encourage people to travel to Iraq and Syria.

item.title: VIDEO: YouTube mogul: 'Follow your passion'
item.description: Jamal Edwards, founder of the SBTV YouTube channel, offers the business advice he wishes he had had when he started out, as part of the BBC News series, CEO Secrets.

item.title: Storm 'on way' and four beached whales
item.description: As Storm Jonas heads across the Atlantic, its potential impact on the UK is the subject of much speculation.

item.title: Can a law abolish snobbery?
item.description: Why does the government feel it has to legislate to force schools to invite in providers of vocational training?

item.title: Gove's actions 'give hope' for justice policy
item.description: Justice Secretary Michael Gove has reversed many decisions taken by his predecessor, Chris Grayling, and struck up better relations with the judiciary, says Joshua Rozenberg.

item.title: A tax deal in the hand is worth two in the bush
item.description: We'd all like to cut a deal with the taxman, but why is it only the big guys who are given the chance?

item.title: Egypt's revolutionaries - where are they now?
item.description: Five years on, the activists who spearheaded the protests in Egypt that led to the overthrow of President Hosni Mubarak have met different fates.

item.title: Massive funnel-web spider to be milked
item.description: Big Boy, a funnel-web spider with a leg span of 10cm, is the largest specimen ever handed in to Australia's only venom-milking programme.

item.title: Banksy's 'Jungle' teargas art hidden
item.description: A Banksy artwork criticising the apparent use of teargas on refugees in the Calais "Jungle" camp which was opposite the French Embassy is boarded up.

item.title: Murray joins Konta in quarter-finals
item.description: Johanna Konta is the first British woman to reach a Grand Slam quarter-final since 1984 - and is joined in the last eight by Andy Murray.

item.title: Russia bans four athletes for doping
item.description: Former European 800m silver medallist Irina Maracheva is among four athletes banned for doping by the Russian Olympic Committee.

item.title: Ex-SA spinner Bodi gets 20-year ban
item.description: Ex-South Africa spinner Gulam Bodi is banned for 20 years after admitting match-fixing charges in a domestic Twenty20 event.

item.title: Adidas to end IAAF sponsorship deal
item.description: Adidas to end multi-million pound sponsorship deal with world athletics' governing body, amid ongoing doping scandal.

item.title: Oil prices in reverse amid Opec call
item.description: Oil prices tumble again on Monday, as Opec calls for co-operation from oil producing nations outside the organisation.

item.title: Breakfast change fuels McDonald's gains
item.description: The introduction of all-day breakfasts in the US helps McDonald's sales rise 5% in the fourth quarter.

item.title: EU vote: Sides clash over single market
item.description: "In" campaigners say full access to Europe's single market is vital for UK businesses, but critics dispute the benefits of EU membership to UK export growth.

item.title: UK 'considering' refugee children call
item.description: The government is considering calls to take in thousands of unaccompanied refugee children who have made it into Europe, a Cabinet minister says.

item.title: Osborne pledges cash to beat malaria
item.description: Chancellor George Osborne and philanthropist Bill Gates announce £3bn in funding over the next five years to tackle malaria.

item.title: Toxic paint levels at playgrounds
item.description: Paint on playground equipment has been found to contain high amounts of the toxin lead - sometimes 40 times the recommended levels, research suggests.

item.title: Faith school places objections limited
item.description: Secularist campaign groups are to be stopped from making "vexatious complaints" against the admissions systems of individual faith schools.

item.title: Schools 'must offer apprenticeships'
item.description: Schools in England will have to give as much time to vocational routes as academic subjects in an effort to help students who want to land apprenticeships.

item.title: Council staff punished for net abuse
item.description: There was a rise in the number of council workers suspended last year after being accused of breaking social media rules.

item.title: Vtech restores some online services
item.description: Children's toy firm Vtech reopens "key functions" of its Learning Lodge gateway for the first time since it was hacked in November 2015.

item.title: VIDEO: Penguin diary: Charting a year in the life
item.description: Victoria Gill joins a team of scientists as they set up remote cameras to observe penguin colonies in the Antarctic.

item.title: Reusable Bezos rocket revisits space
item.description: US entrepreneur Jeff Bezos reflies the New Shepard rocket and capsule system he launched and recovered last November.

item.title: Ofcom: Jekyll and Hyde 'on too early'
item.description: The first episode of ITV fantasy drama Jekyll and Hyde was broadcast too early to be suitable for young children, Ofcom rules.

item.title: X-Files return receives mixed reviews
item.description: Critics are divided in their opinion of the return of the cult sci-fi series The X-Files, which premiered in the US on Sunday.

item.title: Could a Chinese herb stop you drinking too much?
item.description: With new alcohol guidelines stressing the importance of cutting back, could an ancient Chinese herbal remedy help you get that pleasurable buzz while drinking less?

item.title: Does cosmetic surgery really make people feel better?
item.description: Cosmetic surgery is a booming industry. Tom Shakespeare worries about people's urge to alter their bodies.

item.title: Swimming with elephants and sharks
item.description: Swimming with toxic fish and sexy shrimp

item.title: Your pictures: Black and white
item.description: Readers' photographs on the theme of black and white

item.title: How does the lottery investigate damaged tickets?
item.description: How does the lottery investigate damaged tickets?

item.title: The Duchess and the Afghan coat lady
item.description: What happens to people who cannot be identified after death?

item.title: Is Land Rover's off-road heyday over?
item.description: Is Land Rover's off-road heyday over?

item.title: Why do sperm whales wash up on beaches?
item.description: Why do sperm whales die in the North Sea?

item.title: The children who need to play
item.description: The children far from home but determined to play

item.title: China's social media search for stolen children
item.description: Chinese parents are using social media to search for stolen children

item.title: The takeaway worker turned IT boss
item.description: The former takeaway worker who set up a fast-growing IT firm
